docs.snippet: One day, people will not have to type queries into a box to search for information. It will be delivered, via various devices, based on where they are, who is nearby and what they might like and need to know.     Google gave a glimpse of that futu...
docs.lead_paragraph: One day, people will not have to type queries into a box to search for information. It will be delivered, via various devices, based on where they are, who is nearby and what they might like and need to know. Google gave a glimpse of that future last Wednesday at its developer conference in a feature called Google Now. It acts as a kind of automated personal assistant on Android smartphones.

headline.main: From Google, An Assistant Always in Reach

docs.abstract: Bits blog; Google will introduce Google Now, an automated personal assistant for Android smartphones. Photo (M)2

docs.snippet: According to Nielsen, more than 276 million Americans had access to the Internet in May. Of these, 173 million used a Google Web site, and 153 million visited Facebook. The average person visited 97 domains in the month, and had 2,716 page views. ...
docs.lead_paragraph: According to Nielsen, more than 276 million Americans had access to the Internet in May. Of these, 173 million used a Google Web site, and 153 million visited Facebook. The average person visited 97 domains in the month, and had 2,716 page views. The time spent at each property represents the average among all users. In Facebook's case the average may be driven up by people who spend far more than seven hours each month posting and playing Scrabble. In YouTube's case, one hour and 50 minutes still represents a lot of five-minute video segments. SHELLY FREIERMAN

headline.main: Popular Demand

docs.abstract: Popular Demand column features chart illustrating the top-viewed Web sites in May, along with the average amount of time spent on each site. Photo, Charts (S)

docs.snippet: It's no secret that programmers at start-ups are predominantly men. A group of technology companies hopes to change that. On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced that they were joining an initiative called ''Girls Who Code...
docs.lead_paragraph: It's no secret that programmers at start-ups are predominantly men. A group of technology companies hopes to change that. On Tuesday, Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announced that they were joining an initiative called ''Girls Who Code,'' which they hope will increase the number of young women who become programmers and engineers. They want to create a mentoring and teaching program. The Girls Who Code group was founded by Reshma Saujani, a former New York City deputy public advocate, who plans to begin the coding program in New York this summer.

headline.main: Companies Back 'Girls Who Code'

docs.abstract: Bits blog; Twitter, General Electric, Google and eBay announce that they will join Girls Who Code, initiative designed to increase the number of young women who become computer programmers and engineers. (M)

docs.snippet: An article on June 21 about alternatives to using an architect for home construction and renovation misspelled, at one point, the surname of a homeowner who used a software program to design a new kitchen. As the article correctly noted elsewhere,...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article on June 21 about alternatives to using an architect for home construction and renovation misspelled, at one point, the surname of a homeowner who used a software program to design a new kitchen. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, she is Sherry Petersik, not Petrisik. The article also gave an outdated name for a program she used. It is now Trimble SketchUp -- not Google SketchUp, which was its name when Ms. Petersik used it. (Google subsequently sold it to Trimble.)

headline.main: CORRECTIONS

docs.snippet: Silicon Valley is different, they say. One of the most economically creative and dynamic pockets of the United States, it is where entrepreneurs rule. Perhaps it is no surprise then that the men who hold sway in the Valley are now looking to trans...
docs.lead_paragraph: Silicon Valley is different, they say. One of the most economically creative and dynamic pockets of the United States, it is where entrepreneurs rule. Perhaps it is no surprise then that the men who hold sway in the Valley are now looking to transform not only the global economy but the way that public companies are run, locking out both public shareholders and directors. That the call for shareholder rights is a refrain seldom heard in the Internet sector is not new. Since Google went public in 2004 in a way that maintained control for its founders, the leaders of Silicon Valley have been chary about shareholder voting rights.

headline.main: In Silicon Valley, Chieftains Hold Sway With Few Checks and Balances

docs.abstract: Deal Professor column observes that the idea of the visionary chief executive dominates in Silicon Valley, and there may be little room for input from directors or shareholders; points out that in the latest wave of Internet initial public offerings, shareholder voting rights have become even more diminished. Drawing (M)5

docs.snippet: The State of the Art column on Thursday, about the Google Nexus 7 tablet, misstated the music downloading practices of the Google music store. While a song or an album can be downloaded from a personal collection to the Google Nexus 7 only twice u...
docs.lead_paragraph: The State of the Art column on Thursday, about the Google Nexus 7 tablet, misstated the music downloading practices of the Google music store. While a song or an album can be downloaded from a personal collection to the Google Nexus 7 only twice using a Web browser, the user can make unlimited downloads using Google's Music Manager program; it is not the case that Google's music store allows only two downloads of a song.

docs.snippet: 7:17 p.m. | Updated SAN FRANCISCO - Google and the Federal Trade Commission are near a $22.5 million settlement agreement related to charges that Google bypassed privacy settings in Apple's Safari browser to show advertisements, according to a per...
docs.lead_paragraph: 7:17 p.m. | Updated SAN FRANCISCO - Google and the Federal Trade Commission are near a $22.5 million settlement agreement related to charges that Google bypassed privacy settings in Apple's Safari browser to show advertisements, according to a person briefed on the proposed settlement. The $22.5 million fine would be the largest privacy-related settlement in F.T.C. history. It comes as the commission investigates Google for antitrust violations and cracks down on privacy missteps by tech companies, including Google, which last year agreed to pay for any future privacy blunders as part of a separate F.T.C. settlement.

headline.main: Google Is Said to Accept Fine in F.T.C. Privacy Case

docs.abstract: Google and the Federal Trade Commission are said to be near a $22.5 million settlement agreement related to charges that Google bypassed privacy settings in Apple's Safari browser to show advertisements; if passed, it will be the largest privacy-related settlement in the FTC's history. (M)

headline.seo: Marissa Mayer Hopes to Brighten User Experience at Yahoo
headline.main: Mayer Hopes to Brighten User Experience at Yahoo
headline.print_headline: Mayer Hopes to Brighten User Experience at Yahoo

docs.abstract: Google executive Marissa Mayer joins Yahoo as its fifth full-time chief executive in five years; analysts say her challenge will not only be to resuscitate a struggling company, but to avoid the fate of many other experienced executives who have been unable to attract advertisers and increase revenue at Yahoo; Mayer's first challenge will be to articulate a vision for the firm.

docs.snippet: 9:06 p.m. | Updated  Marissa Mayer, one of the top executives at Google, will be the next chief of Yahoo, making her one of the most prominent women in Silicon Valley and corporate America.     The appointment of Ms. Mayer is consider a coup for Y...
docs.lead_paragraph: 9:06 p.m. | Updated Marissa Mayer, one of the top executives at Google, will be the next chief of Yahoo, making her one of the most prominent women in Silicon Valley and corporate America. The appointment of Ms. Mayer is consider a coup for Yahoo, which has struggled in recent years to attract top talent in its battle with competitors. One of the few public faces of Google, Ms. Mayer, 37, has been responsible for the look and feel of some of the search company's most popular products.

headline.main: Yahoo Search Calls Up Chief From Google

docs.abstract: Yahoo hires Google executive Marissa Mayer as its chief executive, making her one of the most prominent women in Silicon Valley and corporate America; Mayer faces a daunting task as the company tries to remain relevant in an ever-changing technological world. (M)y

byline.original: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and EVELYN M. RUSLI

docs.snippet: SAN FRANCISCO -- It is as if there is a revolving door to the executive suite at Yahoo. So many have filed in and out over the years: Terry Semel, Jerry Yang, Carol Bartz and Scott Thompson. On Tuesday, Marissa Mayer, a Google executive, will join...
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO -- It is as if there is a revolving door to the executive suite at Yahoo. So many have filed in and out over the years: Terry Semel, Jerry Yang, Carol Bartz and Scott Thompson. On Tuesday, Marissa Mayer, a Google executive, will join the company as its fifth full-time chief executive in five years. Her challenge will not only be to resuscitate a struggling company, but to avoid the fate of so many other experienced executives who have run Yahoo.

headline.main: Mayer Hopes to Brighten User Experience at Yahoo

docs.abstract: Google executive Marissa Mayer joins Yahoo as its fifth full-time chief executive in five years; analysts say her challenge will not only be to resuscitate a struggling company, but to avoid the fate of many other experienced executives who have been unable to attract advertisers and increase revenue at Yahoo; Mayer's first challenge will be to articulate a vision for the firm. Graph, Photos (M)

docs.snippet: Marissa Mayer has blazed several trails in Silicon Valley -- as Google's first woman engineer, as one of its most high-profile executives when she oversaw its search business and as a  serious technologist who was also willing to show her feminine...
docs.lead_paragraph: Marissa Mayer has blazed several trails in Silicon Valley -- as Google's first woman engineer, as one of its most high-profile executives when she oversaw its search business and as a serious technologist who was also willing to show her feminine side. Now she will blaze a new trail, as a pregnant woman taking the helm of a major technology company.

headline.main: Yahoo Chief's Challenge? Corner Office, New Baby

docs.abstract: Yahoo's new chief executive Marissa Mayer is challenging the idea that senior executive ambitions and a woman's family life are conflicts of interest by tackling a difficult corporate technology job at a major public company while expecting a new baby. Photo (M)/

headline.main: Where Is Google C.E.O. Larry Page?

docs.abstract: Larry Page has lost his voice and been a no-show at Google events for a month, including the company's quarterly earnings conference call on Thursday. Google has offered few details about his condition other than to say he is still running the company, but people briefed on his health said it is not a serious health issue.

headline.main: Google Raises the Maps Bar

docs.abstract: Google announced significant improvements to maps in 11 countries, using an in-house project called "Ground Truth." Google says it believes that geographic data is much more accurate if it comes from one source. What it means is that Microsoft, Amazon and Apple better be prepared to spend a fortune to even approach Google.

docs.abstract: Google reports second-quarter profit of $2.79 billion, or $8.42 a share, from $2.51 billion, or $7.68 a share, in the year-ago quarter; revenue was $12.21 billion, up 35 percent from $9.03 billion.

headline.main: Lavish Pay Helped Lure Yahoo Chief

docs.abstract: Yahoo discloses it offered a five-year pay package worth as much as $129 million to new chief executive Marissa Mayer--if she can turn around the company; it is larger than the pay package of the average chief executive in Silicon Valley, but not the largest among chiefs of publicly held technology companies. (M)

headline.main: How a Cellphone’s Case Can Imitate Its Maker
headline.print_headline: How a Cellphone’s Case Can Imitate Its Maker

docs.abstract: Randall Stross Digital Domain column argues that Google's new smartphones and tablets, which are easy to take apart and fix, may be symbolic of its effort to become a conspicuous alternative to Apple; notes that Apple has become a famously closed company that strongly discourages users from repairing or altering its products themselves.

headline.seo: Colleges Awakening to the Opportunities of Data Mining
headline.main: Big Data on Campus

docs.abstract: Data mining is reshaping the college experience by predicting how well students will do in certain courses, keeping tabs on how they are doing in their majors and even suggesting friends; use of such technology on campuses raises questions about the role of professors and exploration in an increasingly quantified world.

headline.main: Daily Report: Judgment Day for Facebook

docs.abstract: Google customizes advertisements based on what you search for - unlike Facebook, which customizes ads based on who you and your friends are. An important test of how well Facebook is doing will come on Thursday, when it releases its first earnings numbers since going public, Somini Sengupta reports in Monday's New York Times.

docs.snippet: As its share price has plummeted, Facebook has scrambled to attract advertisers away from Google. Its first earnings report since going public will indicate how it is doing....
docs.lead_paragraph: As its share price has plummeted, Facebook has scrambled to attract advertisers away from Google. Its first earnings report since going public will indicate how it is doing.

headline.seo: Facebook Advertising Efforts Face a Day of Judgment
headline.main: Facebook Efforts on Advertising Face a Day of Judgment
headline.print_headline: Facebook Advertising Efforts Set to Face a Day of Judgment

docs.abstract: Facebook scrambles to lure advertisers away from Google as its share price continues to plummet following its disappointing initial public offering in May and leading up to its first earnings report since going public; marketers are unsure if advertising on Facebook offers a return on investment.

docs.snippet: Voice recognition technology is critically important, not just for mobile phones, but potentially for control of lots of other devices, particularly televisions. It is still early days, but if you're thinking about which side  will win in the batt...
docs.lead_paragraph: Voice recognition technology is critically important, not just for mobile phones, but potentially for control of lots of other devices, particularly televisions. It is still early days, but if you're thinking about which side will win in the battle between Apple's Siri and Google Voice Search, consider the lesson of spell check. When Eric Schmidt was still chief executive of Google, I asked him what the company owned that would make it particularly hard for any emerging search contender to wipe Google out. Spell check, he said. Google had observed the spelling mistakes and corrections typed into billions of queries, and had a vast understanding of what people really meant when they typed like thsi. Google was able to use this knowledge to offer a ''did you mean'' function in search, eventually completing queries before people were finished typing.

headline.main: Spell Check And Siri Queries

docs.abstract: Bits blog on the importance of spell check as voice recognition technologies advance; Google's expertise in this area may give the company an advantage over its competitors. (M)

headline.seo: Google and European Commission Move Toward Antitrust Settlement
headline.main: Google Moves Toward Settlement of European Antitrust Investigation
headline.print_headline: Google Moves Toward Settlement of European Antitrust Investigation

docs.abstract: European Commission says that it has reached an agreement with Google that could lead to a settlement of an antitrust investigation into allegations that the company abused its dominance of the Internet search and advertising markets; Google's search engine has a 90 percent market share in many large European markets, compared with less than 70 percent in the United States, where it is also under investigation.

docs.snippet: What makes the perfect chief executive? If the way corporate boards at Yahoo and Duke Energy picked chief executives is any indication, it may be up to chance in large part.     Take Marissa Mayer, the newly appointed chief of Yahoo. She is a Stan...
docs.lead_paragraph: What makes the perfect chief executive? If the way corporate boards at Yahoo and Duke Energy picked chief executives is any indication, it may be up to chance in large part. Take Marissa Mayer, the newly appointed chief of Yahoo. She is a Stanford graduate, age 37, and Google's 20th employee. Until her new gig, Ms. Mayer was one of Google's stars and helped develop Gmail. She was a well-known face for Google, serving on the board of Wal-Mart Stores, attending White House state dinners and appearing as a regular member of Fortune's 40 under 40 of the hottest young business executives. In the ultimate sign of tech prominence, she has almost 200,000 Twitter followers.

headline.main: How Picking a Chief Executive Is More Random Than Wise

docs.abstract: Steven M Davidoff Deal Professor column on how companies go about choosing a chief executive; says much of the selection is left up to chance, with little solid research on what makes an effective chief; suggests that a consequence of the uncertainty in the process is reflected in the high failure rate, making the choice more random and mostly a product of the board's vision and personalities, acting on their own biases. Drawing (M)

headline.main: Google Unveils Superfast Internet in Kansas City, Mo.

docs.abstract: Google unveiled Fiber, its long-awaited Internet service that it says will operate at a speed 100 times faster than a typical broadband connection, in Kansas City. The company, which says it is trying to spur innovation, has put broadband providers on edge.

docs.snippet: The European antitrust chief said that any changes Google offered to settle concerns that it might be tilting Internet search results in its favor should be applied worldwide....

headline.main: Europe Says It May Seek Global Rules for Google
headline.print_headline: Europe Says It May Seek Global Rules For Google

docs.abstract: European Union competition commissioner Joaquin Almunia says that any changes Google offered to make to settle antitrust concerns about its Internet search offerings should be applied globally; confirms that Google was moving toward a settlement, insisting that he would scrutinize other areas that raised competition concerns regardless of any agreement.

docs.snippet: Tired of having to calculate the time in different parts of the world when scheduling events in Google Calendar? Thanks to an optional feature tucked away within the software's settings, you can add a customized world clock to your calendar screen...
docs.lead_paragraph: Tired of having to calculate the time in different parts of the world when scheduling events in Google Calendar? Thanks to an optional feature tucked away within the software's settings, you can add a customized world clock to your calendar screen to keep the current time in various cities in sight. To add the World Clock feature, log into Google Calendar, click the gear-shaped settings icon on the right side of the screen and select the Labs option. On the Labs page, which lists a number of experimental gadgets and widgets, scroll down to World Clock and click the Enable button. When you have finished adding Labs features, click the Save button to add them to the Google Calendar page.

headline.main: Tip Of The Week

docs.abstract: Personal Tech Tip of the Week on an optional feature in Google Calendar that adds a customized world clock to keep the current time in various cities in sight. (S)

docs.snippet: The search engine differentiates itself from Google by concentrating on answering specific questions....

headline.main: Ask.com Heralds a New Focus

docs.abstract: The search engine differentiates itself from Google by concentrating on answering specific questions.

docs.snippet: In the world of search engines, Google's dominance has propelled it to a permanent place as a verb in dictionaries. But another Web site named after a verb wants to own the business of answering questions. On Friday, Ask.com began an advertising c...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the world of search engines, Google's dominance has propelled it to a permanent place as a verb in dictionaries. But another Web site named after a verb wants to own the business of answering questions. On Friday, Ask.com began an advertising campaign with the hope of getting more people to visit the site when they have questions like ''What's the best way to make a potato salad?'' or ''Who killed J.F.K.?'' ''People aren't looking for a new search engine,'' said Doug Leeds, the chief executive of Ask.com. ''They are satisfied with Google.'' Mr. Leeds said Google is a place to do research ''where you just want a whole bunch of sites that point you in the right direction.''

headline.main: Ask.com Heralds a New Focus

docs.abstract: Media Decoder blog highlights advertising campaign by Ask.com. Photo (M)9

docs.snippet: Google indefinitely delayed shipment of the Nexus Q, its spherical black device for playing music and video, after initial reviews that the device does not do enough. It is central to Google's efforts to compete with Apple and other companies by c...

headline.main: Google Delays the Nexus Q After Poor Reviews

docs.abstract: Google indefinitely delayed shipment of the Nexus Q, its spherical black device for playing music and video, after initial reviews that the device does not do enough. It is central to Google's efforts to compete with Apple and other companies by connecting home devices to the Internet, starting in the living room.
